nodes.bodyText: Do we need to pass serializers here? could this be internal implementation detail of KafkaProducerFactory? You could change KafkaProducerFactory to always create KafkaProducer<byte[], byte[]> (no need for generics).
it is not used here.
added to ProducerMessage
Why is this user error?
Good point, I added a few new KafkaErrorCodes and changed that exception
I think this check is not needed.
PlainTextKafkaProducerFactory is not extendable, there is no need to install this module here. Install it in KafkaConnectorFactory in a normal way.
Why do you need this try-catch?
NoSuchMethodException is thrown by class.getConstructor() if the constructor doesn't exist

Why not just
        binder.bind(PlainTextKafkaProducerFactory.class).in(Scopes.SINGLETON);
Injection is new to me, didn't know I could do that lol
Why is it an user error?

make sure you are using unique code:
kokosing@m16:~/presto$ git grep '0x0101_0000'
presto-record-decoder/src/main/java/io/prestosql/decoder/DecoderErrorCode.java:        errorCode = new ErrorCode(code + 0x0101_0000, name(), type);

Why do you use io.prestosql.plugin.kafka.KafkaErrorCode?
It is not unique right now. Same value is used in DecoderErrorCode. I think @findepi  pointed that out in previous review.
I deleted EncoderErrorCode because I don't use the error code in this pr, I think it might be better to just add a KAFKA_ENCODER_ERROR to KafkaErrorCode in the future
separate commit
separate commit

fieldNames.indexOf(..)?

io.prestosql.spi.type.Varchars#isVarcharType
Do we need to be synchronous here? Maybe we should just wake up sender here and return the future we got from last producer.send call?
producer.send returns a Future, not a CompletableFuture
is there a way to wake up the sender using the producer?

This also brings my attention to error handling. What would happen in current codebase if writing operation fails? Would that be propagated to INSERT query in presto. Maybe producer.close(); would fail in such case but I am not sure. Do you know?

is there a way to wake up the sender using the producer?

Good point. Without it the code I pasted will not work. As the sending may basically not happen ever.
So maybe we need explicit flush() here or in finish().
Does producer.close() we call in finish() also flush the sender queue. I skimmed Kafka code and it does not seem so.
It feels the safest for now to get back to what you had originally - flush after each page. And improve in followup PRs as we get more understanding.

that looks great, thank you! I think that you're right about handling exceptions in the onCompletion callback method. The docs for KafkaProducer say that producer.close() blocks until all previously sent requests complete.

that looks great

Not that much really :) - unless we can trigger actual sending to happen It is prone to starvation. As I wrote above. I think safest would be to do what you did originally to flush after each page or only in finish.
ok, we can come back to this later. Seems like it would still be smart to have a callback with an onCompletion method to handle any errors.

Defensive copy properties. Or maybe just drop the parameter because you are binding it to empty properties anyway.
If we actually need the parameter add the marker annotation @ForKafkaProducer as Properties commonly used type and you can easily need to bind multiple instances at different places in the codebase. As an example look for @ForBaseJdbc
removed properties from constructor
prepare properties in the constructor.

please rename the put methods to putObject, putLong, putInt ...
Having that many overrides is very error prone. Especially when there are built-in type conversions in the language between the types for which you provide overrides.
Maybe we should have a constant for this?

if the encoder params are used just for the avro data schema, would it make sense to just pass an Optional<String> that stores the dataSchema? The map seems like overkill, and is kinda clunky, for just one variable.
It would seem more appropriate for this method to return an Optional<String>.
Maybe putValueFromBlock? I do not know why but when I see putValueAt method which takes block I think it will be putting something into the block (though blocks are not mutable).
Also can't you put default implementation already here?
right, that could definitely be confusing
I think so, would just be the same thing as what was in KafkaPageSink#appendColumn
We should probably close the producer here, as well.
You don't need this.
Do we need this method?
no, I'll remove it
This is not absolutely required, as close() calls flush().
Even if I get the byte array before it's closed?
No, I missed the fact that the return is in the try-with-resources.
The check for whether the column is valid happens at a higher level.  I don't think this should be the encoder's concern.
right, I noticed that internal columns don't ever seem to make it to the encoder
You could use functional style here, too.
Would you mind moving to the previous place, before getName, to match ctor params?

Unused, remove.
FYI #4330

Since order of columnHandles is of utmost importance here,
this should be a list.

reorder methods in the order in which they are used (logically):

putValueFromBlock (or appendValue)
toByteArray
clear

The encoders will see every column and some encoders (like CSV or RAW) care getting data
in order. Since encoders are initialized with the list of columns, they know the columns.
By passing column index rather than column handle, we can save lookup like here
io.prestosql.plugin.kafka.encoder.csv.CsvRowEncoder#getPosition
Furthermore, we can guarantee that columns are being provided in order.
This would unlock certain optimizations in encoders like CSV or RAW, which
would be writing to a byte buffer directly.
To express this in the method signature, I would remove the column parameter
altogether.
Third, we could weave in the ConnectorSession session during encoder initialization,
this would allow encoder to precalculate ("compile") encoding strategies for each
of the columns, if it wishes to do so.
Therefore I propose to have this as the signature:
/**
 * Adds value for the next column to the row being encoded.
 */
void appendValue(Block block, int position)

The position argument here represents the index of the column from the table schema, which is not necessarily the same as the position in the result set, so we will still need a mapping (though it would be just an array lookup).

Furthermore, we can guarantee that columns are being provided in order.
This would unlock certain optimizations in encoders like CSV or RAW, which
would be writing to a byte buffer directly.

I don't know if that's necessarily the case.  It would be pretty constraining for the API to require values be provided in the order columns appear in the table schema.
Perhaps we would be better off passing the entire page, instead of individual blocks, and let the encoder decide how to iterate over columns.

The position argument here represents the index of the column from the table schema

block+position represents a value (position is the row)

void appendValue(Block block, int position)

As discussed offline w @charlesjmorgan  -- appendNextColumnValue

I don't know if that's necessarily the case. It would be pretty constraining for the API to require values be provided in the order columns appear in the table schema.

Why is that constraining?
Wha would be the advantage of relaxing this?

The position argument here represents the index of the column from the table schema

block+position represents a value (position is the row)

Sorry, that was a dumb comment.
Where my head was at is that you might have a table schema like foo (x varchar, y bigint, z boolean) and you run INSERT INTO foo (z, y) VALUES (true, 42), so if you don't specify the column, you need to perform a mapping for the column index from the result set schema to the table schema.

Why is that constraining?

In the example above, you'd have to append null, then 42, then true.  It seems like it requires a lot of work for the API client.

this would allow encoder to precalculate ("compile") encoding strategies for each
of the columns

By this do you (@findepi) mean that the encoder could create a list of write functions for the different column types similar to the jdbc connector?
Are columns in pages always in the same order?
I'm worried that key columns and message columns being in the same page might mess up the ordering

also I'm not sure if the name append... really fits if we specify the position to put the value at.
edit: on second thought I think append makes sense if we have an internal index counter. So a method that appends an array of blocks and increments an index counter field and then helper methods that append individual values and use the index field to put the values in the right places

It looks like pages always have the columns in the same (correct) order which is good

Ah, my incorrect assumption was that only the columns specified in the insert are going to be present on the page.  That makes my concern irrelevant.

By this do you (@findepi) mean that the encoder could create a list of write functions for the different column types similar to the jdbc connector?

it can, if it wishes to do so
i am not saying "do it". I am just saying "it is possible"

Are columns in pages always in the same order?

yes

@aalbu I think that this is a good point. My only worry is that if we pass the entire page to the key/message encoder then the page includes both the key and message columns so it would need some way to distinguish these.

That's a very good point, which actually rules out passing full Page (+ position)

The interface has 3 actual methods:

putValueFromBlock (or appendValue)
toByteArray
clear

All the other, default methods are not used by users of the interface.
They are convenience methods added for the sake of the implementations.
Move them to AbstractRowEncoder (as protected).

As noted elsewhere:

Set columnHandles -> List columnHandles
add ConnectorSession session (as first arg perhaps)

Naming is fine. As for the annotation,  drop it (and one below) in separate commit.

nodes.bodyText:
properties is mutable, so defensive copy would be needed here

change Properties properties field to Map<...>  properties and initialize it using ImmutableMap
by using Map<String, Object> you can call the overload of KafkaProducer that does not require you to convert to Properties

I think we should do some additional validation on the columns here.  For example, if the table schema specifies a key, we would need to ensure that all key columns are present.  We could also do the check for internal columns here - make sure that only supported ones are present.
All columns are present by means of io.prestosql.spi.connector.ConnectorMetadata#supportsMissingColumnsOnInsert
Thanks.
This should go to previous commit.

nodes.bodyText: The callback can be run in very different thread than the one calling producer.send. Do we know if exception thrown by the callback will be always propagated back to Presto thread. I.e if we do not get exception directly here, will we still get it on producer.flush() called from finish()?
the callback is executed in the I/O thread of the producer. It doesn't look like flush throws any exceptions other than InterruptException
that sounds good!

It cannot return different list than one we pass to it as an argument, right? Otherwise the columHandles stored here would not be compatible with loop which calls to appendColumnValue. Change to void (unless I miss something).
It only returns a different list as a defensive copy, I don't think that this should affect how it functions
I think we should do the defensive copy in AbstractRowEncoder and make validate return void so it is obvious it cannot change the list.
right, would be best to have validateColumns only validate the columns rather than validate-and-copy the columns
checkState that currentColumnIndex < columnHandles.size()
should we checkState that currentColumnIndex == columnHandles.size()?
yes, that would be a good idea
I actually think this belongs in toByteArray, not in reset. So that if not all columns are appended previous row values can't be duplicated.
not really needed right?
If we make sure that every index is updated for every row then no it is not needed
do we support overriding special characters on read? If so we should also support them on write.
You mean like using something other than a comma to separate the values?
Yep. Or different quote char.
I don't see anything about that in the docs for read so I'm gonna say no it doesn't. Would be a nice feature tho
make it return long.
nit s/'%d'/%d/
Capitalize Kafka in commit messages and (if there are occurences) comments.

nodes.bodyText: Any idea if we can write a test which triggers errorcounter?
hmm not that I can think of, I'm not sure how to intentionally make a producer fail to send a record.

I wonder if we need this method at all.  Perhaps the contract could be: add data, then generate the record, rinse, repeat.  Generating the byte[] could reset things (that would be an implementation detail).

+
+public interface RowEncoder
+{
+    /**
+     * Adds the value from the given block/position to the row being encoded
+     */
+    RowEncoder appendColumnValue(Block block, int position);
+
+    /**
+     * Returns the encoded values as a byte array
+     */
+    byte[] toByteArray();
+
+    /**
+     * Resets the encoder so that it can be used for the next row
+     */
+    void reset();
